title: 104_s1715
content: The "Adoption Promotion Act of 1996" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code allowing for a credit for adoption expenses. The Adoption Promotion Act of 1996 introduced a new section in the Internal Revenue Code allowing for a credit against the tax imposed for qualified adoption expenses paid or incurred by an individual with respect to the adoption of a child. The credit is subject to limitations, including a dollar limitation of $5,000 ($7,500 for a child with special needs) and an income limitation. The Adoption Promotion Act of 1996 introduced a new section in the Internal Revenue Code allowing for a credit against the tax imposed for qualified adoption expenses paid or incurred by an individual with respect to the adoption of a child. The credit is subject to limitations, including a dollar limitation of $5,000 ($7,500 for a child with special needs) and an income limitation. The amount by which the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeds $65,000 bears to $30,000. No credit shall be allowed for expenses with a deduction or credit under any other provision, or if funds are received from a Federal, State, or local program for the expense. The credit allowable under subsection (a) can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year if it exceeds the limitation imposed by section 26(a). No credit can be carried forward beyond the fifth taxable year after the credit arose. Credits are treated on a first-in first-out basis. The term 'qualified adoption expenses' includes reasonable and necessary fees directly related to the legal adoption of an eligible child, excluding expenses from surrogate parenting arrangements. Special needs adoptions may include additional expenses. The term 'qualified adoption expenses' excludes expenses for adopting a spouse's child. An 'eligible child' is defined as an individual under 18 at the time of adoption. A 'child with special needs' is one deemed unable to return home by the state and has specific factors affecting them. The text discusses the eligibility criteria for adoption assistance, including factors like membership in a minority group or medical conditions. Married couples must file joint returns for this purpose. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1995. Distributions from certain plans can be used without penalty to pay adoption expenses. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code allow distributions from certain retirement plans to cover adoption expenses without penalty, up to $2,000. Effective for payments and distributions after December 31, 1995. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code now allow exclusion of amounts received under employer's adoption assistance programs. This is covered under a new section, SEC. 137, which follows section 136. The Internal Revenue Code allows exclusion of employer-paid adoption expenses for employees through adoption assistance programs. Gross income of an employee does not include such amounts, with limitations on the maximum exclusion per child and income limitations. The Internal Revenue Code allows exclusion of employer-paid adoption expenses for employees through adoption assistance programs. An adoption assistance program is a plan where the employer provides employees with adoption assistance, subject to income limitations. Adoption reimbursement programs for armed forces and Coast Guard members are also considered adoption assistance programs. The Internal Revenue Code allows exclusion of employer-paid adoption expenses for employees through adoption assistance programs. Adoption assistance programs are treated as adoption assistance programs for tax purposes. Qualified adoption expenses are defined in section 23(d) of the Code. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections in the Code. The amendments made by this section regarding adoption assistance programs and cross-references to other Acts will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
